intro: Gilia dianthoides, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the tribe Phrymaceae and is characterized by its showy, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as deserts and rocky soils, and is well adapted to drought conditions. Its leaves are linear and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branching. Gilia dianthoides plays an important role in supporting pollinators like bees and butterflies in its native habitat.
